title: Fed faces questions about future of emergency lending
text:
We have made a few changes to the newsletter to highlight more prominently the big themes of 2021: the rollout of vaccines and the state of the global economy. We will also feature more data from our range of Covid trackers.

Please do forward this newsletter to friends and colleagues who might find it valuable. Even if they are not subscribers to the FT, they can read the newsletter — and all of the FT — free for 30 days. And if this has been forwarded to you, hello and welcome. Please sign up here. 

Get the latest worldwide picture with our vaccine tracker

Latest news

  • The WHO has approved use of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine for all adults and recommended a gap of 8 to 12 weeks between doses

  • School catch-up in England could take five years, according to the government's education recovery tsar

  • Mexico has become the first foreign country to approve China's CanSino vaccine, the third China-developed jab to get the go-ahead overseas

For up-to-the-minute coronavirus updates, visit our live blog

Fears that US central bank could drive up inflation

A speech from Jay Powell, US Federal Reserve chairman, later today will be closely watched for any signs that the central bank is returning to “normality” and planning to wind down its emergency coronavirus programmes. 

The FT Editorial Board reminds us that the Fed's traditional role is to “take away the punchbowl just as the party is getting started”, but said its commitment to keeping rates low through to next year could in fact be “spiking the punch”, leading to higher inflation. But new data today showed core consumer prices remained unchanged in January for the second month in a row.

Across the Atlantic there was some more decisive news as the European Parliament gave the go-ahead to the EU's “Recovery and Resilience Facility”, the main chunk of its €750bn coronavirus recovery package, offering a mix of grants and loans to member states. This Big Read examines how countries such as Italy plan to spend the EU recovery money. 

The global economy remains in a fragile state, says chief economics commentator Martin Wolf, and has “long economic Covid” and a “decade of disappointment” to look forward to, unless it acts more firmly to stamp out the virus.

Vaccinating the world is the key, he argues, but this has been hampered by lack of action by rich countries to help their poorer counterparts, exemplified by the underwhelming response to the WHO's Covax scheme to ensure developing countries get their fair share of vaccines.

There was some good vaccine news today, however: BioNTech/Pfizer said its coronavirus vaccine offered two-thirds protection after just one shot. Global stocks hit a record high after the announcement.

Global economy

Manufacturing and construction are powering China's economic recovery, according to new data that show the price of goods leaving the country's factories rose for the first time since the start of the pandemic as the cost of raw materials increased. Exports have also enjoyed strong growth.

UK retail sales and consumer spending in the UK have been hit by the current lockdown, despite a big rise in online transactions. Government ministers have ditched plans to announce a new industrial strategy in favour of a post-pandemic “plan for growth” led by the Treasury. The regions are feeling the squeeze: at least 12 English councils are in rescue talks as the pandemic devastates revenues.

Global economic recovery faces a new threat from a plunge in skilled migration, the OECD said. Countries such as Australia and New Zealand that did well in containing coronavirus have lost up to 80 per cent of their normal inward flows.

Business

Heineken, the world's second-largest brewer, is cutting 8,000 jobs — 10 per cent of its workforce — after reporting a net loss of €204m for the year as lockdown closures of bars dented its revenues. Fewer than 30 per cent of bars and restaurants were operating in Europe by the end of January. Coca-Cola reported a similar story: these outlets normally account for half its annual sales.

The UK has four companies involved in making vaccines and two rapid response centres under construction. This story shows how government support for a vaccines task force helped Britain expand its vaccine manufacturing capacity with hopes of attracting pharma companies back to the country.

Tourism in Spain — which normally accounts for 12 per cent of GDP and 13 per cent of employment — has been battered by the pandemic. The loss of a second consecutive holiday season could mean many more hotels joining the 500 already shut over the past year. Tui, Europe's largest tour operator, was more optimistic, believing the introduction of vaccines would enable it to run 80 per cent of its normal programme this year.

Markets

Markets for raw materials could be on the brink of a “supercycle” as prices jump at the prospect of a stimulus-driven economic recovery. Gains for commodities, out of fashion with investors for almost a decade, have been spurred by demand from China — the world's biggest buyer of natural resources — and have included jumps in prices for soyabeans, copper and oil. This article is part of our Runaway Markets series.

Europe's debt markets are feeling the benefit of EU recovery programmes. Spain has reaped more than €65bn in orders for a new 50-year bond while borrowing costs in Italy have hit new lows. “From a borrower's perspective . . . subdued European government bond yields, along with generally historically flat curves, have made issuance activity at the extra-long end particularly attractive,” said UniCredit, the Italian bank.

The market for US car loans is another that has done well during the pandemic, with the prices of bonds backed by the loans hitting new highs. Retail demand for new and used cars has remained strong, although some carmakers such as General Motors have been hit by the pandemic-fuelled shortage of semiconductors. Japanese manufacturers such as Toyota have been less affected by the dearth of chips.

The essentials

Should Britons give up on hopes for a summer holiday following strong negative signals from ministers? Read our Q&A.

Many of us have made the switch from office to home, but what about those younger workers for whom remote working is all they know? Unless businesses address mental health problems caused by isolation and “hyper-connectedness”, writes author Elizabeth Uviebinené, “we will be sleepwalking into a post-pandemic culture of absenteeism, high staff turnover and lowered productivity”. Register here for the FT conference on the future of work on March 9.

Have your say

Trotters Up comments on Making a good job of remote work:

“For homeworking, see an exaggeration of the previous decade's experience with outsourcing. The reality is often different to the theory, which means both positives and negatives need to be addressed realistically with an open mind. A cost is still a cost whether it is hidden or accepted from the start.”

Final thought

Gyms may be closed but we have plenty of recommendations for keeping body and mind healthy during the dark days of lockdown. Here's our guide to fitness tech, from the best e-bikes to the essential feel-good gadgets.
